places.generalDescription: The War Remnants Museum stands as a poignant testament to the Vietnam and Indochina wars, showcasing an array of photographs, weapons, and artifacts that narrate the harrowing tales of conflict. Situated in Ho Chi Minh City, this museum is dedicated to preserving history while educating visitors about the impacts of war on Vietnam. It serves not only as a repository for historical evidence but also aims to instill a sense of peace and solidarity among nations.

sources.snippet: The War Remnants Museum in Saigon is definitely not a fun attraction to visit. But it is a place to remember the atrocious and horrible effects that come as a result of war. Most of the inside of the War Remnants Museum is filled with photography, shown in exhibitions, about various events of the Vietnam War.

places.name: War Remnants Museum

reviews.text:
Visiting the War Remnants Museum in Ho Chi Minh City was one of the most powerful and emotional experiences of my trip to Vietnam. I went in expecting to learn about history, but I left with something much deeper: a profound reflection on humanity, suffering, and resilience.
The exhibits-especially the photographs-were deeply moving. Some images were so raw and disturbing that I almost cried while walking through the galleries. I found myself needing to pause and take time to process what I was seeing. The human cost of the Vietnam War, especially for civilians, was heartbreaking.

What struck me most was how personal the museum felt. It doesn't just present facts or military artifacts; it shows the faces, names, and lives of people affected-both Vietnamese and foreign. The section on Agent Orange and its lingering effects across generations was particularly difficult to take in.

I left with a heavy heart but also with a greater understanding of Vietnam's past and an even stronger appreciation for the strength and kindness of its people today. Despite everything the country endured, I was met everywhere with warmth and openness. This visit changed the way I think about war, history, and reconciliation.

If you're in Ho Chi Minh City, I believe this museum is a must-visit. It's not easy, but it's important.

Amazing little museum. 3 floors of information pertaining to the Vietnam war and it's lasting effects. In particular, I found the ‚ÄúWar Photographers‚Äù section to be captivating‚Ä¶a lot of stories in there about journalists all over the globe that were intent on capturing the war and the brutality therein, often times paying the ultimate price for their attempts to broadcast the truth. The entire museum could easily take 2-4 hours if you're intent on reading all the descriptions (provided in Vietnamese and English).

One small note - I didn't see any warnings, but some of the content in here can definitely be unsettling. I'm glad they haven't shied away from this, as it's important to show the horrible effects of the war directly. But there are quite a lot of pictures of dead and mutilated bodies, especially within the ‚ÄúWar Crimes‚Äù room. Also, there's a large section dedicated to the health ramifications of Agent Orange, showing the deformities (in both children and adults, Vietnamese and foreign) and mental conditions caused by that horrible chemical. I saw a lot of families with young kids in here, and a lot of the children had slightly terrified looks on their faces. I assume if it was affecting to me, it may have been doubly so for them. Again, I recommend coming and not turning your face away from the horrible facts and effects of the war, but if you're sensitive or have young children who may not be mentally prepared for such imagery, you may want to avoid certain exhibits that you feel could include such photographs (mainly War Crimes and Agent Orange are the two areas that are disturbing, I haven't included any pictures from them below).

If you're in Saigon even a little bit interested in the history and lasting effects of the war, this is a must-visit museum. I visited on a Saturday afternoon and it was crowded, but still easy to see everything.

BEWARE of Coconut saler around this area! There are many of them on every corner.
We visited the museum on Monday the 1st of Sept before Vietnam 80th National Day so the museum was way too packed! The building has 3 levels consist of 7 rooms of war history timeline, consequences, and what's happening now. Some of the contents can be very scary especially the photos captured during the war.
The ground floor outside has the replica of jail (Tiger Cages) and torture chamber used by the Vietnamese government to deal with local rebellious. Many army tanks, planes and transport were displayed in front of the building.
Definitely interesting to see the war history from the perspective of Vietnamese at this museum.

places.generalDescription: Independence Palace, also known as Reunification Palace, stands as a significant historical landmark from the Vietnam War era. This architectural gem showcases South Vietnamese modernist design from the 1960s and offers visitors an immersive experience into its storied past. As you wander through its five floors, you'll encounter fascinating sights such as a recreation room and a bunker basement filled with vintage communication devices like phones and radios, alongside tactical maps that tell tales of strategic planning during tumultuous times.

sources.snippet: Now a museum, but still used for official government meetings and events, the Independence Palace was the former home of the president of South Vietnam during the Vietnam War. After buying a ticket you can then go inside, and walk around a few of the floors to see all sorts of rooms including meeting rooms, dining rooms, and lounges that are fit for royalty. Every room and space within the Independence Palace is still furnished with original chairs and tables.

places.name: Independence Palace

reviews.text:
Visited the Independence Palace in Ho Chi Minh City and it was such a fascinating experience! üáªüá≥‚ú® The place is full of history and gives you a real sense of the country's past. Everything is very clean and well preserved, and the staff were friendly and helpful throughout the visit.

It's not just educational but also really impressive to walk through the different rooms and halls. Definitely a must-see when you're in Ho Chi Minh City! üåü

I recently visited Independence Palace, and I must say, the experience was quite memorable. The palace is absolutely huge much bigger than I had expected. It felt like I was walking through a never ending maze of grand halls, historic rooms, and long corridors. After a while, I actually started to feel tired from all the walking! If you're planning to explore the entire palace, definitely wear comfortable shoes and be prepared to spend a good few hours there.

One thing I noticed and something that did affect the experience was that many parts of the palace didn't have air conditioning. Given how hot and humid the weather was during my visit, it got quite uncomfortable in several sections. Some rooms were noticeably stuffy, and at times I found myself rushing through just to get back to cooler areas.

That said, the architecture and historical significance of the palace are undeniable. The design is both elegant and symbolic, and each room seems to hold a story of its own. I especially enjoyed the presidential meeting rooms and the war command center in the basement both were fascinating glimpses into Vietnam's past.

Overall, while the lack of AC in many areas made the visit a bit exhausting, the sheer scale, historical richness, and grandeur of the Independence Palace still made it worth the trip. I'd recommend it, but maybe plan your visit during cooler parts of the day.

Entry fee was 80,000, so not expensive
Tour the Historic Rooms: Explore the president's office, state rooms, and war command room.
View Artifacts and Exhibits: See historical objects and photographs from the Vietnam War era.
Walk Through the Gardens: Enjoy the beautifully landscaped grounds surrounding the palace.

A must-see for anyone curious about Vietnam's modern history.

places.generalDescription: The Ho Chi Minh City Opera House, also known as the Municipal Theatre of Ho Chi Minh City, is a stunning 19th-century French colonial building that serves as the home to the city's ballet and symphony. Designed by renowned architect Eugene Ferret, this ornate masterpiece was originally constructed in 1897 as a symbol of entertainment for French colonists. The opera house features an elegant facade reminiscent of the Petit Palais in Paris and is located at the beginning of Le Loi Avenue.

sources.snippet: Considered to be one of the best representations of French colonial architecture in Saigon, the Opera House theater was built in 1897, and has been beautifully preserved. If you are interested, the Opera House hosts A O Show, a performance of traditional Vietnamese dance using bamboo. I didn‚Äôt go to the show, but if you are interested in live performances, I‚Äôm sure it would be pretty cool to see ‚Äì especially since it takes place in a such a glorious building.

sources.snippet: Hosting events such as concerts, plays, operas and orchestral performances, the Opera House is a wonderful night out for a couple. (Inquire their website for any future dates) Sit back, and marvel at a splendid show. And if you‚Äôre not in the mood to pay top money for a show, there‚Äôs a stall that sells peach tea for only 15 000VND near the Opera House ‚Äì so grab a tea or two, and mingle in the crowd.

places.name: Saigon Opera House

reviews.text: Very ornate and beautiful. (Check out my review of the A O Show (‚ÄúBamboo Circus‚Äù - a must see event at this Opera House. I would recommend buying tickets online (we bought ours about 5 weeks ahead) to get ‚Äòbest seats', however, a couple close to us on the front row say they bought their tickets the previous day from the front of the Opera House.

Attending the A O Show at the iconic Ho Chi Minh City Opera House was one of the most memorable experiences I've had in Saigon. The venue itself is stunning - a beautifully preserved French colonial building, elegant yet intimate, right in the heart of the city.

The show was nothing short of magical. Through acrobatics, contemporary dance, and live traditional music, it told a wordless yet deeply emotional story - from peaceful village life to the hustle of modern urban Vietnam. The performers were not only skilled but full of soul, using bamboo props and body language to convey meaning with grace and creativity.

As a Vietnamese, I felt truly proud to see our cultural identity portrayed so artfully on an international stage. What moved me the most was the audience's response - endless applause from visitors across the globe. Those claps weren't just for the show; they were a powerful recognition of the beauty and depth of Vietnamese culture.

üé≠ Highlights:
‚Äì Mesmerizing visual storytelling with no spoken words
‚Äì Authentic live music and impressive choreography
‚Äì Intimate atmosphere, perfect lighting and sound
‚Äì Deep emotional connection, regardless of nationality

It is just ok. I was not impressed maybe because I have seen opera houses such as in Sydney, Budapest and Vienna. The building is beautiful and well maintained but it is very small and it is surrounded by vehicles which it loses its aura. However, I recommend you visit the opera house and especially in the night. The energy is very unique and you feel happy and relaxed. For those who visited bigger operas they will understand what I mean when I say I was not impressed.

places.generalDescription: Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon, also known as Duc Ba Cathedral, is a stunning 19th-century Catholic basilica located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City. Built between 1863 and 1880 by French colonists, this architectural marvel showcases unique French design with its red brick exterior and Romanesque bell towers reaching a height of 58 meters.

sources.snippet: Probably not quite as grand as the Notre Dame de Paris, but nevertheless an important cathedral and landmark in Ho Chi Minh City, the Notre Dame Cathedral marks the center of the French colonial heritage in Saigon. They still hold services on Sunday if you‚Äôre interested, but if you just go to visit on any other day, make sure you arrive either in the morning from 8 am ‚Äì 11 am or in the afternoon from 3 pm ‚Äì 6 pm. When I went, I arrived right and noon lunchtime, and the gates were locked; So make sure you plan to visit during open hours so you can get inside.

places.name: Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon

reviews.text: Notre-Dame Cathedral Basilica of Saigon is a majestic French-built landmark in District 1. Its red-brick twin spires, stained glass windows, and ornate interior convey serenity amid bustling downtown. Currently under thorough restoration (active since 2017, now expected to finish by 2027), work includes roof repairs, tower stone replacement, cross restoration, new ventilation, and a future pipe organ. Renovation is careful and respectful - Masses continue, though scaffolding and fences limit access. Expect ambiance, history, and still-unfinished charm.

Despite it is currently under renovation (April 19th 2025) and mostly covered with scaffolding, you can see parts of the Cathedral, testimony of the French presence period.
Not far from the Opera House and the Post Office.
You can also see the Cathedral from the uppest level of the Diamond Plaza Mall

The Notre Dame Cathedral of Saigon, built between 1863 and 1880 by French colonists, is a key landmark in Ho Chi Minh City. Featuring Romanesque architecture with a striking red brick facade and twin bell towers, it was constructed to serve the French Catholic community and remains a symbol of Vietnam's colonial past. We had seen its beauty online, but unfortunately, due to renovations, the church was completely covered, leaving nothing visible. Despite our bad luck, we still managed to take a few pictures to capture the moment. Later, we hoped to enter inside to pray, but once again, luck wasn't on our side. The watcher informed us that a function was taking place, and tourists weren't allowed to enter.

The zoo features a variety of animals like giraffes, camels, elephants, snakes, big cats, komodo dragons and more. The botanical gardens boast over 1830 trees and 260 plant species including orchids, cacti, and bonsai.

sources.snippet: Clustered together in the same park, is both the Saigon Zoo and the Botanical Gardens. Instead of having to pay for both attractions, you just pay a single entrance fee and you can then walk around both. places.name: Saigon Zoo & Botanical Gardens

reviews.text:
We recently visited the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens in Ho Chi Minh City with our family and had a delightful experience.  The zoo is one of the oldest in the world and offers a blend of wildlife and lush greenery.

Tips:

Best Time to Visit: Arrive early to enjoy cooler temperatures and more active animals.

Amenities: Bring water and snacks, though refreshments are available on-site.

Accessibility: The zoo is centrally located and easily reachable by taxi or bus.

In summary, the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens provided our family with an enjoyable and educational day out, combining wildlife, greenery, and cultural heritage in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City.

The Saigon Zoo and Botanical Garden is a sprawling green oasis in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City, offering a refreshing escape from the urban hustle. As one of the oldest zoos in the world, it holds a significant place in the city's history and provides a unique experience for visitors of all ages.
The park is a pleasant surprise, with its vast grounds filled with ancient trees and a wide variety of plants. It's not just a zoo; the botanical garden aspect is a major draw, providing a beautiful and tranquil environment for a leisurely stroll or a family picnic. The peaceful atmosphere and the sounds of nature make it a perfect place to relax and unwind.
While some of the animal enclosures may not meet modern standards, the zoo is home to a diverse collection of creatures, from majestic elephants and big cats to a variety of birds and reptiles. It's clear that it is a popular spot for local families, and the low entry price makes it an accessible and enjoyable day out.
Beyond the animals and plants, the complex also houses the Museum of Vietnamese History, adding a cultural and educational dimension to the visit. You can easily spend several hours here, exploring the grounds, observing the animals, and even enjoying some of the amusement park-style rides available.
For those seeking a quiet retreat with a mix of history, nature, and wildlife, the Saigon Zoo and Botanical Garden is a worthwhile destination.

We decided to spend the afternoon at the Saigon Zoo before our evening flight. I had visited a few years ago and wasn't particularly impressed, but I'm glad I returned. There has clearly been a lot of work put into the zoo, and the experience is now so much better.

We were able to see meerkats, otters, bears, elephants, giraffes, monkeys, iguanas, and a wide variety of birds-plus so much more. The zoo is quite spacious, offering plenty of shade and walking areas, which makes it easy to explore without feeling crowded.

Another highlight is the affordability of the entrance fee, which makes it accessible to families and budget travellers. There are also interactive feeding zones that add to the experience and make it more engaging for visitors of all ages.

Overall, Saigon Zoo is well worth a visit if you have a few hours to spare in Ho Chi Minh City. It's a relaxing and enjoyable way to see a wide range of animals in the heart of the city.

places.name: Landmark 81

reviews.text:
Recommended. Nice place to visit. Landmark 81 is a skyscraper located in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam. It's part of the Vinhomes Central Park development, which is a large-scale urban project aimed at transforming the area into a modern residential and commercial hub. Standing at 461.2 meters (1,513 feet), Landmark 81 is the tallest building in Vietnam and one of the tallest in Southeast Asia. You can visit 81 floor at 382,65 m. In the ground floor there is and ice skating ring.

The building has a mix of uses, including luxury apartments, a hotel, offices, retail spaces, and even an observation deck with stunning views of the city. It's known for its sleek design and distinctive architecture, with a sharp, modern silhouette that makes it a striking addition to the city's skyline.

Landmark 81 offers a breathtaking experience from 81 floors up, with a serene, almost surreal view of Ho Chi Minh City sprawling below. Inside, the posh and golden interior adds a touch of luxury, making every corner feel grand and elegant. While the daytime view is impressive, I believe it would be even more magical at night, when the city's vibrant lights come alive. Watching the city sparkle from that height would be an unforgettable sight, perfect for a romantic or reflective evening. (There is also a VR experience available, just didn't get to try!) Best if booked in advanced.

Landmark 81 ‚Äì Observation Deck Review

Landmark 81 is the tallest building in Vietnam, and its observation deck offers one of the best panoramic views of Ho Chi Minh City. The observation area spans from the 79th to the 81st floors, with the 81st floor featuring an open-air terrace, allowing you to step outside and enjoy the fresh air along with the view.

The views are absolutely stunning - a 360-degree panorama of the city, the Saigon River, and the skyline. I highly recommend visiting between 17:30 and 19:00, so you can experience the city transform: first in daylight, then watch the sunset, and finally see the skyline light up at night.

Standing at a remarkable height of 178 meters, this glass-enclosed observation deck provides a stunning panoramic vista that captures both the vibrant cityscape and the serene curves of the Saigon River. Visitors can take advantage of six high-tech telescopes that allow for an immersive exploration of distant landmarks from various angles.

sources.snippet: Speaking of the city‚Äôs culture, it would be criminal not to mention the cultural shows put on at various venues around the city. Attending these cultural shows at night is one of the most romantic things to do in Ho Chi Minh City. places.name: Saigon Skydeck

reviews.text:
I had an amazing experience at Saigon Skydeck! The ticket prices were very affordable, and the 360¬∞ views of the city were absolutely stunning. The staff were kind and welcoming, and we also received complimentary water with our tickets.

I loved the cultural displays-there was an engaging section about the traditional Vietnamese dress the ao dai and how it has evolved over time. Another highlight was the interactive bamboo structure-visitors could add their own small bamboo sticks to a growing installation, which was such a creative and meaningful experience to be a part of.

Overall, it was a great mix of breathtaking views and rich cultural insight. Highly recommend!

The Saigon Skydeck, located on the 49th floor of the Bitexco Financial Tower in Ho Chi Minh City, offers breathtaking 360-degree panoramic views of the city. The observatory is a must-visit for anyone looking to experience the vibrant skyline of Saigon, especially during clear days or just before sunset. The glass windows provide an unobstructed view, making it a perfect spot for photography enthusiasts.

Visitors can enjoy additional features such as the Ao Dai exhibition, interactive information panels about the tower, and large screens that highlight key landmarks in the city. The Skydeck also has a souvenir shop for those looking to take home memorabilia. The experience is enhanced by the modern amenities, including air conditioning and binoculars for a closer look at distant attractions.

The ticket prices are reasonable, with discounts available for children, seniors, and disabled individuals. The Skydeck is open daily from 9:30 AM to 9:30 PM, allowing ample time to explore and soak in the views. Whether you're a local or a tourist, the Saigon Skydeck is a fantastic way to appreciate the beauty of Ho Chi Minh City from above.

Had a great time at Saigon Sydeck! The view from the deck is amazing, especially around sunset - you can see the whole city skyline, and it's such a peaceful spot to unwind. The staff were super friendly and made us feel welcome right away. I grabbed a drink and just hung out for a bit; it was a nice break from the busy streets below. It's definitely one of those hidden gems in the city that's worth checking out, whether you're a local or just visiting. Would absolutely go back!

places.generalDescription: Ben Thanh Market is a must-visit destination for anyone exploring Ho Chi Minh City. This bustling hub offers an authentic glimpse into Vietnamese daily life, showcasing a vibrant mix of handicrafts, clothing, and local delicacies. As one of the city's busiest markets, it‚Äôs the perfect spot to indulge in delicious street food while shopping for unique souvenirs and home goods. The lively atmosphere extends into the night market area, where visitors can savor popular dishes amidst the energetic buzz of city life.

sources.snippet: Like I mentioned at the top of this list of top attractions in Ho Chi Minh City, I really liked Binh Tay Market, but there was no way I was going to leave out Ben Thanh Market either. Even as touristy as it may be, it‚Äôs a buzzing market, full of history, shopping stalls galore, and being located in the heart of Ho Chi Minh City‚Äôs District 1, it‚Äôs probably the most important central landmark of the city. You‚Äôll find just about everything ever created or produced in Vietnam somewhere within the market lanes of Ben Thanh.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Start your adventure by wandering through the labyrinthine alleys of Ben Thanh Market. Indulge your taste buds in the culinary delights of Vietnam as you sample an array of street food delicacies from roadside stalls and local eateries. places.name: Ben Thanh Market

reviews.text:
A Must-Visit Market for Culture, Food & Souvenirs
Ben Thanh Market is one of the most iconic and vibrant spots in Ho Chi Minh City. It's a great place to explore if you're into local culture, street food, and souvenir shopping. The market is packed with stalls offering everything from traditional Vietnamese clothing and silk scarves to spices, coffee, and handmade crafts.
The food section is especially exciting-plenty of local dishes like pho, fresh fruit smoothies, and sweet treats. It's a great place to try authentic Vietnamese flavors in a lively setting.
The market can get busy and a bit overwhelming, but that's part of the charm. Bargaining is common, so don't hesitate to negotiate prices. There are also fixed-price stalls if you prefer a more straightforward shopping experience.
Centrally located and open until late, it's a convenient stop whether you're shopping, eating, or just soaking in the local vibe.
THERE IS NO AC PLEASE TO WEAR Sleeveless DRESS

B·∫øn Th√†nh Market sits right in the heart of District 1 and is considered one of Saigon's most iconic landmarks. Inside, you can find just about everything ‚Äì from dried foods, coffee, spices, and local specialties to souvenirs, clothing, handicrafts, and even delicious street food.

The atmosphere here is lively and bustling, especially in the mornings and late afternoons. Visitors come not only to shop but also to soak in the vibrant pulse of the city.

However, prices at B·∫øn Th√†nh Market are often not fixed. Many stalls tend to quote higher prices, especially to foreign tourists or those unfamiliar with bargaining. To get a fair deal, it's best to check prices at several stalls, compare, and negotiate comfortably ‚Äì after all, haggling is part of the authentic Vietnamese market experience!

Overall, B·∫øn Th√†nh Market is well worth a visit if you want to catch a glimpse of old Saigon, pick up some local specialties, or find unique souvenirs. Just remember: don't rush to buy from the first stall you see.

The place is well kept, and the dry market section is fairly organized with sections for 1-day coat/dress making, shirts, cute souvenirs trinkets, dried fruits & nuts, loose leaf tea and coffee beans.
The prices vary but sellers offer huge discount especially when you buy more than 1 item.
Just be cautious as some sellers can be very persistent.
Despite the crowd, I feel safe walking around because there's plenty of uniformed officers patrolling, and stationed around the market.

places.name: Cu Chi Tunnel

reviews.text:
We visited the Cu Chi Tunnel on Sunday. It is one of Vietnam's most significant and popular historical attractions, located approximately 55 km (around 1.5 hours) from Ho Chi Minh City.

I highly recommend visiting with a guided day tour rather than going on your own. There is so much detailed history to learn about the Vietnam War that only a knowledgeable guide can explain effectively. The tunnel system here is incredibly extensive, stretching over 250 km underground as our guide shared.

What you will see and experience here:
‚Ä¢	Narrow tunnels built for escaping and hiding during the war
‚Ä¢	Small spaces and hidden rooms where soldiers used to stay undetected
‚Ä¢	Underground kitchens with cleverly camouflaged smoke outlets
‚Ä¢	Weapon-making rooms and storage areas
‚Ä¢	Sleeping areas, meeting rooms, and various underground living setups
‚Ä¢	Models explaining war strategies, traps, and daily life of Vietnamese soldiers

The most fascinating part is experiencing the tunnels yourself. The tunnels are extremely narrow, dark, and complexly interconnected. It is truly unbelievable how soldiers moved and lived inside them. It was difficult even for us to crawl a short distance, and experiencing it gives you an immense sense of respect for their courage and endurance.

Additional notes:
‚Ä¢	The entire site is located amidst a dense forest area. If the weather is hot, it can feel extremely humid and uncomfortable, so carrying water, a cap, and wearing comfortable shoes is highly recommended. In pleasant weather, the walk becomes enjoyable.
‚Ä¢	There is a large souvenir shop to buy local items and handicrafts.
‚Ä¢	You can also try shooting at the shooting range (note: this activity is chargeable and not included in the entry ticket).
‚Ä¢	Entry ticket costs around 125,000 VND, and I have uploaded a photo of the ticket for reference. This was included in our day tour package.

Overall, visiting Cu Chi Tunnel was an inspiring and humbling experience, showcasing the intelligence, resilience, and determination of Vietnamese soldiers during the war. If you are in Ho Chi Minh City, this place is a must-visit to witness an extraordinary part of Vietnam's history.

If you visit Vietnam the Cu Chi tunnels are as the ware museum a must to get a understanding of the history of this country. You get a feeling about jungle live in different station. Most impressive, with going trough this narrow tunnels. But just do it if you feel comfortable with that! We did it with a tour from Ho Chi min, is recommendable.

If you are going to go here, make sure you find a guide who knows a lot about the place. The travel is a bit farther out, so you will want to make the most of it. Some of the tour offers you will find on Klook have guides who will take you there and share some basic information, but if you want to enjoy the experience, make sure you find a knowledgeable guide.

That said, we still enjoyed being able to see the tunnels, the displays, and the bunkers. You will have the option to walk through some of the tunnels aside from the famous photo op where you lift the cover of the manhole. There are tanks there and also a shooting range, but we didn't opt to try that out.

It's hot, so bring a cap and water, and a mini-fan if you have it. Expect a lot of walking and dust. Remember that it's a literal part of a jungle so don't expect it to be like other museums or educational experiences!

places.name: HCMC History Museum

reviews.text:
A Peaceful Walk Through Vietnam's Past

We visited the History Museum of Ho Chi Minh City early in the morning, right when it opened  and that turned out to be the best decision. The place was peaceful and nearly empty, allowing us to explore without any crowds. By the time we left, more visitors had started arriving, so if you prefer a quiet and calm atmosphere, definitely try to go when the doors first open.
The museum is beautifully arranged, guiding you step by step through the fascinating history of Vietnam. From ancient civilizations to more recent events, each section flows naturally into the next. We especially enjoyed the displays on ancient wars, traditional weapons, and the evolution of Vietnamese culture. Seeing swords, armor, and other artifacts up close gave us a deeper appreciation of the country's resilience and rich heritage.
What really stood out was how everything is laid out in a way that's easy to follow, even if you're not a history buff. It feels like traveling through time  and learning about Vietnam's past in one thoughtfully curated package.

The museum itself is housed in a beautiful colonial era building, and the peaceful garden outside adds to the charm. It's not a massive museum, but it's packed with meaningful displays and doesn't overwhelm you with too much at once.
Overall, it was a highlight of our trip. Whether you're just curious about Vietnam's roots or already passionate about Southeast Asian history, this museum is well worth a visit. Just remember to go early for the best experience!

This place is definitely worth visiting to dive deeper into the history of Vietnam and gain a better understanding of the country's unique character. It provides a solid foundation for exploring other locations, like the My Son Sanctuary. We spent about 1.5 hours in the museum, and it has a rich and diverse exhibition. Not far from the museum are the famous Jade Emperor Pagoda and a botanical garden, both of which are worth checking out if you're in the area.

BEWARE coconut saler scam in the area!
Chaotic day to go anywhere on the 2nd of September, the 80th National Day.
The museum is partly in construction but still has a lot to go see! I love the little pond and garden after the entrance. There are many interesting facts and pieces of history here in this museum! The zoo next door was insane!

places.name: B·∫øn B·∫°ch ƒê·∫±ng

reviews.text:
The 45-minute boat tour was a great surprise. On the rooftop of a boat, with some explanations about the city and a stunning view.

There was even one free drink, and a saxophonist performing-a completely unexpected bonus.

A fantastic way to explore the city.

However, the booking website was a bit tricky to access-it was in Vietnamese, and the English version didn't seem to work. The ticket purchase process was also quite long, though it's probably possible to buy them on-site.

Ticket prices varied depending on the seating category (indoor, outdoor, rooftop), ranging from around 100k to 350k, if I remember correctly.

Overall, a great experience.

If you want to hop on the infamous Saigon Waterbus, make sure to choose the time wisely. The best one will be around 5 PM and the return boat around 6.30 PM. That way, you'll get both the day and night view!

With just 30,000 VND (around 1.2 USD) for a return ticket, I'd say it's totally worth it!
If you're looking to explore Ho Chi Minh City in a different way, I genuinely recommend taking this short boat ride along the Saigon River ‚Äì the city's main river. It only takes about 20 minutes from Bach Dang Port to Binh An Port, but the views along the way are beautiful. You'll pass through some of the city's most modern and charming residential areas.

The boat moves slowly, which gave me time to enjoy the cool breeze and take in the riverside scenery.
Definitely a great little experience for anyone who enjoys discovering new sides of the city.

places.generalDescription: Nestled in a charming old-style villa in Saigon, Cuc Gach Quan offers an authentic Vietnamese dining experience. The restaurant prides itself on serving healthy and delicious cuisine made with fresh, preservative-free ingredients. With an interior designed by architect Tran Binh, the restaurant exudes a cozy atmosphere with its rustic decor and lush greenery.

sources.snippet: Enjoy a hearty breakfast at Cuc Gach Quan, known for its traditional Vietnamese dishes. Spend the morning exploring the Cholon (Saigon Chinatown), where you can visit the vibrant markets and historical temples. Don't miss the stunning Jade Emperor Pagoda.
sources.shortName: Romantic Week In Ho Chi Minh City: A Blend Of Culture, Cuisine, And Adventure: Itinerary 2024
Ho Chi Minh for Couples: Enjoy Ultimate Date Spots During Transit - DayDreamHub

places.name: Cuc Gach Restaurant

reviews.text:
Portion is nice.. Manageable size even for couples. If you come with your family or friends, you can order a few more dishes to share. Generally, the food is not spicy and very delicious.
Salad is a great start, for a lighter food, fried tofu is yummy! Love the soup they recommended us. Was a little worried that it's catfish (usually has a muddy taste, but this doesn't have it). I would recommend the stew pork, too. Reminds me of home (bak kuh teh).
Green mango juice is pretty unique too (taste like balong long drink). I enjoyed my lotus tea!
Great service, too. The servers are very attentive. Every now and then, they will check on us.

Great food to be had! It's has lovely garden setting as well. You get the authentic feel but with high quality refined food. The menu is dominated by a great selection of vegetable dishes on offer. Highly recommend coming and trying out. The soft shell crab was spot on, the mango salad was excellent as well. Shout out to the fried rice which was a great accompaniment to the salad. The prices were pretty affordable as well for the type of place.

We were craving rice and home cooking after our trip to Bangkok so we decided to give this place a try.

Food is actually pretty good but extremely overpriced for what it is.

Everything was cooked to perfection and seasoned very nicely. The tofu and fried fish were probably my favourites of the night but everything was pretty tasty.

places.generalDescription: La Villa French Restaurant is a top-tier dining venue in Ho Chi Minh City, known for its exquisite French cuisine and elegant ambiance. Run by a French Vietnamese couple, the restaurant offers a fine dining experience with impeccable service. The owner, Thierry Mounon, brings his expertise as a former 5-star chef to create exceptional dishes that showcase the best of French gastronomy.

sources.snippet: A cut above the rest, a meal at La Villa by Chef Thierry Mounan is more than a pleasurable treat, it‚Äôs a luxury. Housed inside a charming villa, expect white tablecloth service with an impressive cheese trolley and a variety of tasting menus (starting from VND 1.69 mil for lunch) to choose from that feature quintessentially French classics such as Duck Foie Gras terrine and Snacked Hokkaido Scallops with apple compote and sweet cider jus. Don‚Äôt miss the famous apple tart.
sources.shortName: 15 Romantic Restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: Housed in a beautiful and charming old villa, La Villa French Restaurant offers the most authentic French culinary experience with a menu featuring a carefully curated selection of French classics. The soft, elegant decor and lush garden setting create a truly romantic atmosphere.
sources.siteName: Best Fine Dining Restaurant In Hanoi | Red bean Ma May
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Restaurants In Saigon (updated 12.2023): Dine In Love And Luxury

places.name: La Villa French Restaurant

reviews.text:
An exceptional experience. The ambience feels like you've stepped into a classy French restaurant in Paris.

The staff are very attentive and observant.

For the piece de resistance, the meal is one of the best French dinners I've had. The meats are perfectly cooked. The sauces are so well prepared, glossy and sufficiently assertive without being overwhelming. The ratatouille (served with the Patagonia Tooth Fish) was melting, but still had a bit of structure to give an added dimension to the dish.

We will be back (probably during every visit to HCM).

I came here for lunch yesterday, a party of two. It was an extraordinary experience highly recommend to anyone that visit Vietnam! I've been to this restaurant several times, I've never been disappointed. The food was delicious and overall great atmosphere with over the top taste! A 10/10 meal! Will come back soon!

Thierry Mounon's Four Seasons
At La Villa ‚Ä¶

I'm fortunate enough to have now experienced my 4th of the signature seasonal menus at La Villa. Common dimensions of them all include thoughtful souring of world class, rare proteins prepared with classic culinary techniques that elevate the natural characteristics of the ingredients. In a broader sense, the table is always set impeccably thru a sublime hospitality quotient while wine parings typically with an Alsatian|Rhone accent drizzle decadence all over this 13-course epic epicurean experience.

This time, these 5 dishes were especially delightful and kudos to Kaviari caviar who've been the house caviar at La Villa ever since they launched in Vietnam some 10 years ago.

Le Panini ‚Äì Morteau sausage, Tasmanian smoked salmon & wildflower tome with Kristal Kaviari caviar.

Obsiblue prawn flambeed avec pastis Henri Bardouin soft boiled egg with oscietra Kaviari caviar, Vaucluse asparagus cream and asparagus & noir de bigorre emulsion.

Crudo of calamari & kinmedai, chilled artichoke puree with wild garlic & spring vinigarette.

New Zealand <Aotearoa> lamb ribeye, lamb jus with curry, coconut & yogurt with French style baby peas and liver mousse.

Sensational Strawberry & Rhubarb Mega Millefeuille

5,190,000 for 13 course tasting including Les Freres Marchand cheese trolley
Add: 2,790,000 for wine pairing.

Camera: Cecilia Ninh
#LaVillaFrenchRestaurant #FrenchGastronomy #Depuis2011

places.generalDescription: The Golden Dragon Water Puppet Theater is a vibrant venue that showcases the enchanting art of Vietnamese water puppetry, accompanied by live traditional music. This cultural gem in Ho Chi Minh City offers an immersive experience into Vietnam's rich folklore and wet rice civilization, captivating audiences with its unique storytelling through puppet movements on water. Even if you don't speak Vietnamese, the expressive gestures of the puppets convey the narrative beautifully, making it accessible for everyone.

sources.snippet: Another must-see cultural experience is a traditional water puppet show, an integral part of Vietnamese heritage. Performed on water with wooden puppets, the show combines colorful lights and sounds to create a magical experience. It‚Äôs a wonderful way to immerse yourself in the beauty of Vietnamese culture.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: The Water Puppets Show is often conducted in the evening at the Golden Dragon Water Puppet Theater, inside the Labour Culture Palace HCMC.(55B Nguyen Thi Minh Khai, District 1, Ho Chi Minh City) It costs about $4/adult for a ticket.
sources.shortName: 5 Ideas For A Romantic Trip To Ho Chi Minh City

places.name: The Golden Dragon Water Puppet Theater

reviews.text: We watched here and the show was fun. We sat near the stage and the show was live. The singers and musicians were brilliant kudos to all the artist behind every puppet. The aircon was fine here. Food/drinks were not recommended to consume if you'll bring one. Mostly are foreigners though the language used was in Vietnamese. No need to learn the Vietnamese because mostly are in actions and sounds. Light and choreography of the puppets were excellent. Worth your money. We bought our ticket online and claimed the physical ticket thru one of the staff in front of the kiosk. Souvenirs were sold outside after the show and it was not that expensive especially the toys and post cards. Definitely all souvenirs were unique and you can buy it only at that place.

Really unique experience! I wasn't sure what to expect at first, but the water puppet show turned out to be one of the highlights of my trip to Vietnam. The music, the traditional storytelling, and the skill of the puppeteers were all amazing. Even though the narration was in Vietnamese, it was still very easy to follow and enjoy. It's a great way to experience Vietnamese culture in a fun and memorable way. Highly recommend checking it out!

The show was very interesting and full of different little short stories! The music and singing is not in the language we can understand but the movement of the puppets really give off great feel and telling the story! A lot of character and actions don't actually supposed to be in the water though.
I love the fish dance the best! Look absolutely like a real fish splashing around.
Definitely one of a must see for traditional art in Vietnam.

places.generalDescription: Experience a unique and luxurious dining cruise at Saigon Princess. Indulge in a romantic candlelit dinner while cruising along the river, taking in the fresh air and savoring 5-star European-style cuisine. The restaurant offers an exquisite menu prepared by talented chefs using high-quality ingredients imported directly on the day. With its opulent ambiance and top-notch dishes, Saigon Princess is the perfect choice for a special evening in Ho Chi Minh City.

sources.snippet: If you want to give the surprise for the special one, why not choose Saigon Princess Restaurant to enjoy a romantic dinner under the candlelight?. Cruising on the river, breathing in the fresh air and enjoying a 5-star meal in a luxurious European style, that is truly an experience that couldn‚Äôt be more wonderful for dinner in Ho Chi Minh city. The dishes at the restaurant are all prepared by the talented chefs, using all high-class ingredients which are imported directly during the day.

places.name: Saigon Princess - Luxurious Dining Cruise

reviews.text:
My seat was arranged in the indoor area on the lower deck, and I chose a three-course meal. The main course, a steak, was absolutely delicious. The meal included tea or coffee, but additional drinks could be ordered at an extra cost. The live music performance started indoors, and later, the musicians moved to the open-air upper deck for another performance.

There were multiple ways to enjoy the scenery-you could step outside to the lower deck's outdoor area or go up to the open-air section on the upper deck. Personally, I found the lower deck to be a great choice. The dining area was well-lit, and stepping outside immediately offered a beautiful river view with no obstructions. Additionally, the lower deck was less crowded and quieter, allowing for a peaceful and uninterrupted experience of the scenery.

The staff member, Monica, was very warm and welcoming, providing a detailed introduction to the entire cruise. The live performance was also very professional, and the overall ambiance was excellent. Initially, I considered visiting some well-known seafood buffet restaurants in Ho Chi Minh City, but in the end, I chose to take a river cruise on the Saigon Princess, and it turned out to be absolutely worth it. Highly recommended!

Saigon Princess delivered a fantastic dining experience with above-average food that was definitely worth the price. The flavors were vibrant, and the dishes felt well-crafted. Service was excellent-attentive and friendly without being overbearing.

The magic show was a delightful surprise, enthralling everyone at our table! After dinner, the band tried to liven things up and get people dancing, but our crowd was more in the mood to relax and enjoy the ambiance. Kudos to them for keeping the energy high anyway!

Overall, a great spot for good food, entertainment, and a lively vibe. Would definitely return!

Had such a great time on the dinner cruise in Ho Chi Minh City! üåÉüç¥
The staff were super friendly and made us feel really welcome. The food was delicious and the whole vibe on board was just perfect. Cruising down the river at night with the city lights all around was such a cool experience.

Definitely something you shouldn't miss when you're in HCMC - it's the perfect mix of good food, good people, and amazing views!

places.generalDescription: The Mariamman Hindu Temple, located near the Ben Thanh market in Ho Chi Minh City, is a sacred place for the small community of Chinese and Vietnamese Tamil Hindus. Built in the late 19th century by Indian traders, it is dedicated to Mariamman, the Goddess of Rain. The temple is adorned with intricate artwork depicting various Hindu deities and is rumored to possess miraculous powers that bring luck and wealth to its worshippers.

sources.snippet: Another intriguing religious attraction to experience in the city would be the Hindu Mariamman Temple. Similarly, you should also take the opportunity to visit absorbing shrines like the Buu Long Pagoda, Jade Emperor Pagoda, Cao Dai Temple, and Giac Lam Pagoda.
sources.shortName: Romantic Experiences in Ho Chi Minh City ‚Äì Enthralling Things to Do for Couples: pushpitha ‚Äî LiveJournal

sources.snippet: Religious places to see: Saigon Notre Dame Cathedral, Mariamman Hindu Temple, Jade Emperor Pagoda, Buu Long Pagoda, Giac Lam Pagoda and Cao Dai Temple
sources.shortName: ‚úì 10 Most Romantic Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City

places.name: Mariamman Hindu temple

reviews.text: To find a Hindu temple in the middle of the hustle and bustle of Saigon, who would have thought. Pretty interesting history of Tamil traders that came into the country in the early 19th century. I believe most of them have left and the temple is run by a local trustee. It's a mix of Hindu and Buddhist deities and way of praying. I'm amazed that many locals come here to pray too. It's a beautiful vibe. Sit down for a few minutes and soak in the architectural beauty of the temple, the blend of culture and religion, read the history of the temple (Which I think could be improved) and just pray in which ever practise you follow.

The Mariamman Temple in Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City) offers a serene and sacred escape amidst the city's lively hustle and bustle. Nestled in the heart of District 1, this Hindu temple is dedicated to Mariamman, the goddess of rain and disease, and serves as a spiritual hub for both locals and visitors.

The temple's vibrant and intricate architecture stands out with its colorful statues, detailed carvings, and ornate decorations. Upon entering, you're greeted by the scent of incense and the sound of soft chants, which help create a peaceful ambiance that contrasts sharply with the surrounding urban activity. The temple's peaceful atmosphere invites you to pause and reflect, offering a sense of tranquility that feels almost otherworldly amid Saigon's fast-paced energy.

Despite its relatively small size, the temple is a vital part of the local Hindu community, and visitors often come to pay their respects, pray for blessings, or seek protection from ailments. The temple also serves as a cultural touchstone for the Indian diaspora in Vietnam, preserving ancient rituals and traditions that have been passed down for generations.

What makes the Mariamman Temple especially unique is its location in one of the most dynamic areas of the city. Walking through the busy streets, where street vendors and motorcycles bustle by, then stepping into the quiet sanctuary of the temple creates a striking contrast and a reminder of the city's rich cultural and spiritual diversity.

Overall, the Mariamman Temple is an exceptional spot for those interested in exploring the spiritual side of Saigon. Its divine presence amidst the chaos offers a unique experience of serenity and reflection, making it a hidden gem for both spiritual seekers and curious travelers alike.

There's nice deities in this small temple.

It houses nearly 1000 plant species and over 120 different animals, making it one of the largest reserves for old animals in Vietnam. Despite some visitors feeling that the park could use some updates, it offers an entertaining escape from the bustling city.

sources.snippet: A serene date at Saigon Zoo and Botanical Garden will provide a peaceful escape from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle. Take your time to explore lush green areas, visit the animals, and capture colorful photos in this picturesque environment.

places.name: Th·∫£o C·∫ßm Vi√™n S√†i G√≤n

reviews.text:
Saigon Zoo and Botanical Gardens is an underrated gem in Ho Chi Minh City, offering an impressive array of animals and lush greenery at an incredibly affordable price. With an entrance fee of just 60,000 VND (approximately A$3.80), it's a budget-friendly destination for both locals and tourists. Ôøº

During my morning visit, many animals were peacefully sleeping, likely due to the warm weather. Observing them in this tranquil state added a unique charm to the experience, as there's a certain endearing quality to animals-and humans-at rest.

Entry cost 60.000. The whole place felt a bit empty and neglected. You can see monkeys, chimpanzees and iguanas. The butterfly garden had hardly any butterflies, the bird areas were closed to visitors. There was a labyrinth which was fun in guess. Overall overpriced and underwhelming.

The animals looked sad and distressed. Some of them were sick and malnourished. Others violent with each other. We saw a Zebra hit a half blind austrish. The only joy was watching the escaped birds and monkeys hang around with their caged friends to keep them company.

places.generalDescription: The Refinery Restaurant, named after its historical use as an opium refinery, has become a popular brunch spot offering three different menus. The restaurant's French-style ambiance exudes luxury and simplicity, creating a quiet and lovely space for diners to enjoy. The diverse French menu includes special dishes like beef fillet with red wine juices and potato galette roll. Additionally, the restaurant offers top-tier crepes alongside a superb selection of wine, cheese platters, and Western dishes.

sources.snippet: A popular French brasserie and wine bar situated in a quiet courtyard setting off Hai Ba Trung. The Refinery has all the charm and nostalgia of a classic French bistro reminiscent of the French-Chinese Opium era with the right amount of buzz. With both an indoor and outdoor seating area, here you can choose from a selection of cheese and cold cut platters, sixty different types of wine and classic French favourites such as Traditional ‚ÄúSteak Frites‚Äù and Parmentier de Canard ‚Äì Duck Confit ‚ÄúShepherd‚Äôs Pie‚Äù.

places.name: The Refinery Restaurant

reviews.text:
Absolutely love this place! We've been here five times already, and every visit has been amazing. The French cuisine is top-notch - perfect for a casual yet dressy dining experience. The duck magret is always cooked to perfection, juicy and full of flavor. I'm absolutely in love with the anchovy chicken salad - it's perfectly balanced and so well made.

We also tried the cauliflower soup, which was divine, and both the salmon and swordfish. The swordfish had a slightly fishy taste, but the flavors were still incredibly well balanced. And the ratatouille? Genuinely better than what we've had in France - no exaggeration!

Another thing we love is that they serve a simple hot lemon and honey drink - so hard to find elsewhere! And the juices are always fresh and delicious, made without any added sugar or syrup, which we really appreciate.

The staff speaks excellent English and always gets the orders spot on. Manager Mathew has been there every time we visited, keeping everything running smoothly and making sure the service is top-notch. Highly recommend

Living in D1 sure has its perks, and one of them is walking distance access to classic establishment such as The Refinery. Its as French as you can get with the menu here and the service is impeccable. Really fond of the toasted potatoes, slightly crispy on the cover and well cooked on the inside, the pasta can use some improvements but an Italian dish at a French restaurant is never a right choice to make, but still pretty decent. Always love the outdoor seating, especially when its a cloudy day, the vibe is just mellow and relaxing for both lunch and dinner. I don't think I need to recommend this place since its a star on a map for almost every local or visitors coming to Saigon with a culinary mission.

Really enjoyed lunch here. Had the lasagne üçù which was rich and proper comforting and the fish was fresh and cooked spot on. Both dishes hit the spot üëå also profiteroles for dessert were so delicious. ü§§

The place has a laid back charm to it. Tucked away off an alley in a quiet little courtyard under cover in the rain is cool and feels like you're miles away from the chaos of the city. Cold beer, warm fresh bread and butter when you sit down üçûüç∫ Simple things done right.

Juices were good too especially liked the super orange one.

Service was friendly and chill and the whole vibe just felt easy and relaxed.

They also have indoor dining but outside wasn't hot.  I like how dark it is when blind is covered but some might not.

Will 100% come back ‚úÖ.

places.generalDescription: Turtle Lake, located in Ho Chi Minh City, is a unique and popular destination. It features small lakes, spiral pedestrian paths, benches, and old trees. The highlight of the area is a tower shaped like a flower and a sword. Built by President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam, the octagonal lake and four spiral paths are said to keep an invisible power represented by a dragon from awakening.

sources.snippet: Ho Con Rua ‚Äì or Turtle Lake ‚Äì is an artificial lake in the heart of the city. Well, was ‚Äì it‚Äôs been drained, leaving behind a shallow pond of sorts. You might think that such a location is unsuitable for romance, but alas, you have made a mistake.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Best Romantic Getaways in Saigon

places.name: Turtle Lake

reviews.text:
This place is like Saigon's little secret escape from the urban chaos.

Picture this: a quirky roundabout with a turtle fountain that's practically a local landmark. It's like someone thought, ‚ÄúHey, let's put a giant turtle in the middle of a lake and see what happens!‚Äù And it worked brilliantly.

By day, it's a peaceful spot where you can catch your breath. By night, it turns into a street food haven, with vendors serving up everything from fried squid to corn on the cob.

Whether you're there for the oddball charm or just to grab a bite and chill, this place has got you covered. It's a bit of quirky bliss in the middle of Saigon!

The lake and the architecture itself are very nice but the condition of it is very bad. It looks like Noone takes care of this place and things are starting to fall apart. Very sad, could be an amazing place for pictures and to chill/hang out.

Turtle Lake is one of those landmarks tucked away just a 10 minute walk from the Notre Dame Cathedral. It's a large circular pond surrounded by flowerbeds and elevated walkways leading to a striking central sculpture.

Though the upper level of the sculpture is currently closed off, the view from the surrounding bridges still offers a unique perspective of this surreal, retro futuristic design.

Historically, Turtle Lake (H·ªì Con R√πa) was constructed in the 1960s during the South Vietnamese era.

While some parts could use a little upkeep, it's still an iconic spot worth visiting quirky, quiet, and unmistakably local.

places.generalDescription: Bar Eon 52 Heli, situated on the 52nd floor of Bitexco Financial Tower in Ho Chi Minh City, offers a luxurious and romantic atmosphere with breathtaking panoramic views of the city. It features live performances, international DJs, and an extensive selection of drinks including wines, champagne, and cocktails. The highest nightlife spot in the city provides a relaxed ambiance with live bands and acoustic sets earlier in the evening before transitioning to more upbeat music later at night.

sources.snippet: Saigon Saigon Rooftop Bar: Nestled atop the historic Caravelle Hotel, Saigon Saigon Rooftop Bar is an iconic destination for a lovely date with its colonial charm and panoramic vistas of Dong Khoi Street and Lam Son Square.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Romantic Things to Do in Ho Chi Minh City

places.name: Bar Eon 52 Heli

reviews.text: Stunning views and not as overpriced as I thought! This is more for a romantic night while soft and mellow music plays! Not a place for hard party goers looking for a dance floor. Bottle of wine around 35 to 50usd!

The view is pretty incredible, get there about 30-45 before sunset for the light and dark differences. The drinks and food are not the cheapest, but you pay for the view and atmosphere.  The cocktails themselves are delicious, and the food is basic but very well done. The only reason this gets 3 stars is that the service is abysmal. Trying to get staff is difficult and getting the bill was like pulling teeth. They need to invest in mobile card machines and more attentive staff.

Cool bar where to go for a drink. A bit pricey but the views are worth it. When I visit cities, I tend to go to skyscrapers. However, instead of paying to go up I usually go to bar and have a drink. Although the tower looks modern, the atmosphere at the bar is a bit old style. They also have live music.

places.generalDescription: The Museum of Ho Chi Minh City is a vast space spanning 1700 square meters, dedicated to preserving and showcasing a wide array of antiques, artifacts, and historical evidence. With 10 rooms housing different collections such as Nature and Archeology, Administrative Saigon, Revolution from 1954 to 1975, and more, the museum offers visitors an immersive journey through the city's rich history. The building itself boasts a unique design that combines classical European style with Asian elements.

sources.snippet: In the past you might have heard of the Gia Long Palace or the Revolutionary Museum, but now, the same place is officially known as the Museum of Ho Chi Minh City or HCMC Museum. When my wife and I visited, on a weekday in the middle of the morning, it wasn‚Äôt busy at all (unlike the War Remnants Museum which was packed out), so it was nice to peacefully walk around and enjoy the exhibitions. Most of the displays show the history and making of Ho Chi Minh City, and also there are a number of Vietnamese culture exhibits as well.
sources.shortName: 23 Things To Do In Saigon (Ho Chi Minh City): Top Attractions!

sources.snippet: Speaking of the city‚Äôs culture, it would be criminal not to mention the cultural shows put on at various venues around the city. Attending these cultural shows at night is one of the most romantic things to do in Ho Chi Minh City. Popular Culture Shows: Water puppet shows at the Golden Dragon Water Puppet Theater and acrobatics, ballet and musical performances at the Saigon Opera House
sources.shortName: ‚úì 10 Most Romantic Things To Do In Ho Chi Minh City

sources.snippet: An absorbing place to visit in the city would be the Ho Chi Minh City Museum which presents a multitude of artefacts and displays documenting the eventful history and unique culture of Vietnam. Here, you will have the opportunity to learn about the struggles that the Vietnamese undertook to achieve independence.
sources.shortName: Romantic Experiences in Ho Chi Minh City ‚Äì Enthralling Things to Do for Couples: pushpitha ‚Äî LiveJournal

places.name: Museum of Ho Chi Minh City

reviews.text:
Visited on a weekday. surprisingly fewer people than I thought. Tickets were bought at the entrance + guardhouse.

Architecture is stunning and there are countless trinkets showcasing the Vietnamese history and culture etc.

It seems like it's a popular spot from weddings? When I was there, there was a wedding photoshoot happening at the main stairs hence not a lot of pictures there üòì

No air conditioning, but the areas were mostly sheltered and cool. There's only 2 floors to the Musuem, but the non-sheltered areas house the tanks & the planes.

Found the Museum to be pretty cool, worth the money and experience. Advice would be to stay there, take your time to leisurely look around the items, it really contains a lot of stuff from the past that's really interesting haha.

I visited the Museum of Ho Chi Minh City on a Saturday morning and was pleasantly surprised to find it wasn't crowded with tourists. Instead, a few couples were there taking wedding photos, adding a charming and romantic atmosphere to my visit.

Though the museum may not have an extensive collection to explore, it is still a wonderful place for anyone interested in exploring both the past and present of this vibrant city.
It offers valuable insight into the city's rich history and the lives of the people who have shaped it. It's a place that invites reflection, learning, and a deeper understanding of the city itself.

Tickets are quite affordable and easy to purchase on-site, but keep in mind that payment is cash only. There's also a small surcharge if you bring a camera.

Generally a good museum in a beautiful old building, however the building itself needs renovation badly.
The stories presented are great but could be executed and shown way better.
Another issue is that there are dozens of grooms and brides doing their photo shoots. This in itself is nice, but the sheer number of them conflicts with the museums regular operation.
Solution would be separate time slots for visitors and for photo shoots.

places.generalDescription: Giac Lam Buddhist Temple, also known as Giac Lam Pagoda, is a venerable and atmospheric place established in 1744. It is believed to be the oldest temple in Ho Chi Minh City and offers a peaceful setting with garden-like grounds. The temple features many statues, tombs, and a 7-tiered stupa. Visitors can witness daily prayers held at specific times throughout the day.

places.name: Giac Lam Buddhist Temple

reviews.text:
A Serene Escape in Ho Chi Minh City
Giac Lam Buddhist Temple is a peaceful haven that offers a beautiful blend of history, culture, and spirituality. As one of the oldest temples in Ho Chi Minh City, its architecture and atmosphere exude timeless charm.

The temple grounds are impeccably maintained, with lush gardens and towering Bodhi trees that create a tranquil environment. The main pagoda is stunning, adorned with intricate carvings and colorful murals depicting Buddhist teachings. Climbing the stupa provides breathtaking views of the surrounding area, a must for any visitor.

The welcoming monks and staff make the experience even more special, offering insights into the temple's history and practices. Whether you're seeking a quiet moment of reflection or simply exploring the city's cultural heritage, Giac Lam Temple is a must-visit.

Don't forget to take a moment to admire the large Buddha statues and light an incense stick for good luck. Highly recommend for anyone visiting Ho Chi Minh City!
One of the oldest temple in Saigon. Not well maintained. Only the roof and the wooden columns are still authentic. Wall color not nice anymore. Still worth a visit.

It is a peaceful place to visit. The temple has many beautiful Buddhist statues and colorful architecture. Locals come here to worship Buddha and connect with the divine.
There is no entry fee, but you need to pay for parking. A calm and spiritual spot worth visiting.
A moderate dress code to be followed covering knees and shoulder.

places.generalDescription: Saigon Cao Dai Temple, also known as the Holy See, is situated 90km northwest of Ho Chi Minh City in Tay Ninh Province. It serves as the focal point for the Cao Dai faith, a unique Vietnamese religion that blends elements of Taoism, Confucianism, Buddhism, Islam and Christianity. The temple's architecture is a blend of pagoda, cathedral and mosque styles. Visitors can witness the mesmerizing prayers of Caodaists during their visit.

places.name: Saigon Cao Dai Temple

reviews.text: As a member of Cao Dai religion who just visited Thanh That Sai Gon for the 1st time together with my customer, I am surprised and proud of the way Cao Dai brethren welcome tourist visit our temple. Look at these cute little guides. They are intelligence and so much friendly.

Tour guide brought us here for a different aspect of the local temples. You will have to remove your footwear to enter and be split accordingly to gender. The females will enter by the stairwell on the left whilst the males will enter by the stairwell on the right. Devotes would dress in white.

Eclectic and charming place. Truly fusion religion. They even worship Victor Hugo as a diety here. I wonder if Neil Gaiman had this place in mind when he wrote The Graveyard Book and one of the ghouls in the story was The Author Victor Hugo....
